cards.front:
A properly sized blood pressure cuff should cover:

A. one third the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.
B. two thirds the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.
C. one half the length between the armpit and the crease at the elbow.
D. the entire upper arm between the armpit and the crease at the elbow.
See Secondary Assessment
cards.back: two thirds the length from the armpit to the crease at the elbow.

cards.front:
A 29-year-old male with a head injury opens his eyes when you speak to him, is confused as to the time and date, and is able to move all of his extremities on command. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is:

A. 10.
B. 13.
C. 12.
D. 14.
See Secondary Assessment

When performing a reassessment of your patient, you should first:

A. repeat the primary assessment.
B. confirm medical history findings.
C. reassess your interventions.
D. obtain updated vital signs.
See Reassessment

A patient’s short-term memory is MOST likely intact if they correctly answer questions regarding:

A. day and event.
B. person and place.
C. event and person.
D. time and place.
See Primary Assessment

After performing a primary assessment, a rapid exam of the body should be performed to:

A. look specifically for signs and symptoms of inadequate perfusion.
B. find and treat injuries or conditions that do not pose a threat to life.
C. identify less-obvious injuries that require immediate treatment.
D. determine the need for spinal motion restriction precautions.
See Primary Assessment
cards.back: identify less-obvious injuries that require immediate treatment.

cards.front:
In the adult, bradycardia is defined as a pulse rate less than _______ beats/min, and tachycardia is defined as a heart rate greater than _______ beats/min.

A. 60, 100
B. 50, 110
C. 40, 120
D. 30, 130
See Secondary Assessment

The goal of the systematic head-to-toe exam that is performed during the secondary assessment is to:

A. assess only the parts of the body that are injured.
B. detect and treat all non–life-threatening injuries.
C. locate injuries not found in the primary assessment.
D. definitively rule out significant internal injuries.
See Secondary Assessment
cards.back: locate injuries not found in the primary assessment.

cards.front:
Which of the following findings indicates that your patient has a patent airway?

A. Unresponsiveness
B. Inspiratory stridor
C. Ability to speak
D. Audible breathing
See Primary Assessment

Which of the following medical history questions would be of LEAST pertinence in an acute situation?

A. “Does your mother have diabetes?”
B. “Does the pain stay in your chest?”
C. “Has this ever happened to you before?”
D. “Are there medications that you cannot take?”
See History Taking

As you assess the head of a patient with a suspected spinal injury, your partner should:

A. look in the ears for gross bleeding.
B. prepare the immobilization equipment.
C. maintain stabilization of the head.
D. assess the rest of the body for bleeding.
See Primary Assessment

Cyanosis of the skin is caused by:

A. venous vasoconstriction.
B. peripheral vasodilation.
C. increased blood oxygen.
D. decreased blood oxygen.
See Primary Assessment

Capnography is used to:

A. determine how much carbon dioxide is being exhaled.
B. assess how much oxygen is reaching the body’s tissues.
C. trend a patient’s blood pressure and assess for shock.
D. assess how much oxygen is bound to the hemoglobin.
See Secondary Assessment
cards.back: determine how much carbon dioxide is being exhaled.

cards.front:
The goal of oxygenation for most patients is an oxygen saturation of:

A. 90% to 94%
B. 94% to 99%
C. 88% to 90%
D. 100%
See Primary Assessment

A blood pressure cuff that is too small for a patient’s arm will give a:

A. falsely low systolic but high diastolic reading.
B. falsely high systolic and diastolic reading.
C. falsely high systolic but low diastolic reading.
D. falsely low systolic and diastolic reading.
See Secondary Assessment
cards.back: falsely high systolic and diastolic reading.

cards.front:
Which of the following would the EMT likely NOT perform on a responsive patient with a headache and no apparent life-threatening conditions?

A. Focused secondary assessment
B. Noninvasive blood pressure monitoring
C. Assessment of oxygen saturation
D. Systematic head-to-toe examination
See Secondary Assessment

In responsive patients who are older than 1 year of age, you should palpate the pulse at the ________ artery.

A. carotid
B. radial
C. femoral
D. brachial
See Primary Assessment

Treatment and transport priorities at the scene of a mass-casualty incident should be determined after:

A. area hospitals have been notified.
B. all the patients have been triaged.
C. a physician arrives at the scene.
D. medical control has been contacted.
See Scene Size-up
cards.back: all the patients have been triaged.

cards.front:
The systematic head-to-toe assessment should be performed on:

A. stable patients who are able to tell you exactly what happened.
B. all patients with traumatic injuries who will require EMS transport.
C. patients with a significant MOI and unresponsive medical patients.
D. responsive medical patients and patients without a significant MOI.
See Secondary Assessment
cards.back: patients with a significant MOI and unresponsive medical patients.

cards.front:
Which of the following is an example of a symptom?

A. Hypertension
B. Headache
C. Tachycardia
D. Cyanosis
See Introduction

When you use the palpation method to obtain a blood pressure, the measurement you obtain is the:

A. pulse pressure.
B. systolic blood pressure.
C. cardiac output pressure.
D. diastolic blood pressure.
See Secondary Assessment
